The manifold devices of war can be as ingenious as the repeating crossbow or as stealthy as the poisoned blowpipe.\\n\\nSome war machines, however, are neither sophisticated nor subtle. The juggernaut may be slow-moving and hard to manoeuvre, and its operation may require a mixture of knowledge, dexterity and good fortune, but those enemies caught in the line of fire when the juggernaut roars will be destroyed.

Sun Tzu said that one should always give an enemy room to escape, so that they do not fight with the fervour of the doomed. Yet for Gao Shun's elite force, the Camp Crushers, being entirely surrounded is nothing but another dimension to slaughter. \\n\\n Renowned for their abilitiy to smash through enemy formations, the Camp Crushers excel even when surrounded. The bodies will pile high, but the Camp Crushers will still emerge from the pile victorious.

Named after the White Wave Valley they hail from, these rebels have long resisted the corrupt ruling classes by employing guerrilla tactics. This fighting style forgoes any gentlemanly rules of engagement if it means beating the enemy. \\n\\n Years of fighting larger numbers have made them fleet of foot, meaning they can rush to support beleaguered allies or charge quickly into enemy lines to destabilise them. Once engaged, these warriors' skill with sword and shield enables them to hold their own in close combat.

Unconcerned with rough terrain, armoured and strong in defence yet agile and fast, the Might of the Valley are Wuling's greatest warriors. \\n\\nThey wield their massive axes with effortless skill, and when called upon to charge the enemy, they are a sight to strike fear into the heart of any warrior. Should battle go against them, however, they still have more to give, and will fight on to the last without giving in.

Only the most exceptional troops are given the honour of riding the purest of white horses; if the mounts' appearance is not enough to strike fear into their targets’ superstitious hearts, then the riders’ accuracy with their long siyah bows will surely intimidate. \\n\\n The horses are trained to ignore the din of battle, so that their riders can harass enemies with arrows or attack with zhibeidao swords, without fear that their horses will panic and bolt.

Most peasants are not taught the ways of war, rather they are handed the implements of battle and pointed in the direction of the enemy. It is thus fortunate that a bow, although difficult to master, is easy enough to use on a fundamental level. \\n\\n Although these territorial warriors may want for skill, they have a surfeit of zeal - they may draw a clumsy bowstring, but they fire, again and again, with the fiery determination of one defending his home and his life.

The versatility of the spear makes it a vital asset to any army, despite its relative simplicity. The same weapon can be used to throw, defend or attack in melee.  \\n\\nEven the bulkier two-handed spear can be thrown like a javelin, although the number of such weapons an individual warrior can carry is somewhat limited.\\n\\nAfter their initial throw, these spearmen stand ready to lead a charge, or withstand one.

Some call the Nanman barbarians, and their ability to work with wild animals may be held up as testament to that. But man and wolf have a long history, hunting as partners, seeking prey together. \\n\\n That same pack mentality embodies these warriors who, although without their trusted lupine companions, fight their foes with that same ferocity, gorging on the hunt and despatching the enemy with axe, mace or – sometimes, in the heat of the moment - teeth!

These martial arts students have mastered the use of the gun staff, known as the ‘grandfather of weapons’. \\n\\n Effortless action means to act with the flow of nature rather than trying to impose an action against it, demonstrated by the graceful and organic parries of the staff as it mirrors the movement of the body. \\n\\n Each action flows to the next, allowing them to swiftly switch between defence and attack and utilise the minimum amount of energy, so they that they never tire in battle.

The warriors of the Yellow Turban cause have deep roots drawn from all corners of the land. Their styles, therefore, may be unconventional, but their determination and belief is beyond doubt. \\n\\n Those entrusted with delivering the message of the cause ride to battle with a sword in each hand and no armour. This might be a display that some would call crazed, but to see the whirlwind of destruction they wreak upon the battlefield, none can help but be impressed and intimidated.

The role of sword cavalry is to hold the line against enemy attackers; their swordsmanship with the jian – known as the 'Gentleman of Weapons' – along with their leather armour and rattan shields, enables them to stand long after other defenders have fallen. \\n\\n Being mounted, they can race to relieve beleaguered allies and protect them against encroaching threats, but like all cavalry, spears and polearms will pierce their defences.

Whilst bowmen require training and physical prowess, crossbowmen need only load, point and shoot - the mechanism of the weapon does the rest. The bolt punches faster and harder than a bow, and can be used effectively by peasants and noblemen alike, making the crossbow truly deadly in anyone's hands. \\n\\n Sima Jiong's crossbowmen are an impressive, resplendently-armoured sight on the battlefield, and the prowess they display with their weapons gives pause to even the most armoured of attackers.

To serve as a spearmen is to know more of a battle than any other; the veterans, therefore, must be paragons to those who serve alongside them, a standard to aspire to where others would falter. \\n\\n These spearmen have earned commendation and merit in the field against myriad northern invaders – better armed and armoured as befits their station, they are prepared to weather the storm of battle as it rolls across the field towards them.

Zheng Jiang has selected her most ferocious bandits to act as her ‘Fists of the Bandit Queen’; their role is to act as shock-troops, sneaking behind enemy lines to terrify foes with surprise attacks early in the battle. \\n\\n Each carries a heavy fu axe in each hand, and the wounds dealt by them can be catastrophic. Striking terror requires these troops to be without fear themselves, but also means they can tend to be undisciplined and difficult to control once their blood is hot with battle.

As the monsoon rains strike down upon the land, the shock cavalry charge is relentless, persistent and devastating. Cavalry have formed the hammer blow of armies for centuries, and even bandit armies – irregular as they are – know their value. \\n\\n With spears thrust forward, the raiders bear down upon their foes, intent on skewering any in the line before them, and cutting a swathe through the enemy lines.

Only the very finest warriors are chosen for the honour of serving the emperor as frontline troops. Archers of exceptional talent who also show skill with the deadly jian sword are recommended to the emperor as Defenders of Earth. \\n\\n If they pass inspection, they are rewarded with uniquely-crafted jian swords and composite bows to fight on the frontline. Their arrows have small pots of flammable oil affixed to them; the fuses are lit, and the arrow loosed to rain down fire upon their enemies.

When firing at enemies from a distance, these hunters’ arrows may fall short of their targets, but their real strength lies in the ability to sneak up on unsuspecting prey to dispatch them at close range. \\n\\n Creeping deep into enemy territory to launch surprise attacks requires no small amount of courage, and these troops are fearless, thinking only of splitting skulls with their fu axes. \\n\\n However, that same bravery can make them undisciplined and susceptible to the occasional reckless action.

The intention of the Han's northern army was to defend against tribal threats, and if possible to put them to rout. None are better suited to that task than the sabre cavalry. Although their thundering charge is a sight to behold, their true value comes from their endurance in melee. \\n\\n Once the dust has settled from a powerful charge, these horsemen will remain, deflecting blows with reinforced armour, and aiming to shatter morale with savage hacks, slicing through body and mind both.

Although there is wisdom in not overbearing soldiery with too many arms, these warriors prove their right to march with spear, crossbow and shield in hand. Certainly not a task for the untrained, these elite warriors take up formations behind their shields and patiently wait for the enemy. \\n\\n When faced with imminent melee, they unleash a devastating crossbow volley from between their shields before bracing their spears against the onslaught to come.

The nomadic lifestyle of the Qiang tribespeople has honed their skills in cavalry warfare, forging them into an unstoppable force. \\n\\n The power of their cavalry charges is almost unmatched, and once the initial impact of the charge has scattered their foes, they start hacking and chopping at those still standing with expertly made zhibeidao swords. \\n\\n However, no matter how unrelenting they are in spirit, Qiang Raiders' only defences are rattan shields and leather armour, leaving them vulnerable in sustained close combat.

Said to be descended from the god of fire, Lady Zhurong is a formidable general. Whilst others, such as Meng Huo, are great leaders, she shows as much courage and wisdom as they. \\n\\nHer followers are fiercely loyal, well trained, and devastating. Every swing of their great maces sends the enemy sprawling, but there is more – the head of each mace is aflame, and its crushing force is backed up with fire, splashing over the enemy, setting clothes and armour alight.

Many decry injustice, but it takes a unique temperament to travel the land to actively oppose it, and great skill to survive each encounter. Recognising a shared goal, the Youxia join the Yellow Turbans in the fight against tyranny. \\n\\n Their armour and expensive shields are scarred by many battles, testaments to their experience, and their precise swordsmanship demonstrates a discipline rare among those who have achieved some renown. It is this purity of intent that makes them so effective on the frontlines.

Militia are recruited quickly, armed and mobilised in mass numbers, without spending much time on training before deployment. Any conscript who demonstrates some ability in archery is given a composite bow and enlisted as an archer. \\n\\n These archers are considered useful to increase numbers, but less skilful than seasoned soldiers, and so are given zhibeidao swords for protection rather than armour. \\n\\n These straight-bladed swords are cheap but easily mastered, making them the perfect weapon for militia troops.

Enemy infantry fall easily before the Yellow Dragons’ attacks; their fu axes rend flesh with the savagery of a dragon’s fangs, and retaliatory blows bounce off their shields as water from oil. \\n\\n The Yellow Dragons’ empathy and understanding of the land is such that it offers as little resistance to their movements as air, and they cross all terrain types effortlessly and quickly. \\n\\n With this combination of mobility and strength, the Yellow Dragons move quickly through the battle, dispatching the foes and allies of chaos.

If peace is the ideal future to be attained, the Yellow Turbans must be, paradoxically, prepared to fight for it. It is the soldiers who know and accept this truth who will fight the hardest for it. \\n\\n With dual axes, they create a maelstrom of violence when wading into battle. Those enemies fortunate enough not to be cleaved in two are sent sprawling before the might and unbreakable spirit of these Yellow Turban zealots.

In ages past, the tribes of the south held together as one unified band, significant enough to be known as the state of Yue. With the advent of the Han, however, such places and titles are no longer fitting, as the Yue have fractured. \\n\\n The disparate remnants of the state are scattered across the vast southlands, clinging to their lineage. They refuse to relent, offering their strength to any who would help them retain their freedoms and their culture.

Heavily armoured and rigorously trained, these lancer cavalrymen are the keen blade that cuts through the heart of enemy formations. Commanded by an experienced captain, they are leaders on the field of battle, and the sight of their deadly charge is enough to fortify even the weariest spirit amongst their allies. \\n\\n In the absence of a great general, their peers may rest assured that the day will not be lost. It is clear that these men of the north stand ready to fight under the leadership of this brave lancer cavalry and their trusted captain.

Though the fire of the Noble Rebellion is all but spent in the land, the slimmest guttering embers still burn in the hearts of these warriors. Remnants of the last noble rebellion would be usually marked for death, yet Cao Cao offered them mercy for service. Although they welcome the blade's reprieve, they show little enthusiasm for their new fight. \\n\\n Scarcely armed, these fighters will break quickly – however, their long-dimmed fervour will sometimes burst forth, surprising all with their zeal and ferocity.

It takes years of training and immense upper strength to be able to draw back the bowstring to the nocking point. Firing a crossbow needs the user to be taught only how to load a bolt and point it. \\n\\n Unlike notching an arrow, however, a crossbow bolt can be loaded easily and held until the user is ready to fire. \\n\\n Despite its ease of use, the draw-weight increases the bolt's speed and power when released, meaning that less-skilled troops can be armed but still prove deadly on the battlefield.

Those warriors who seek to inherit the gift of the Eight Immortals must show extreme endurance and martial skill, as well as great dedication to mediation and the quest for enlightenment. \\n\\n  They are armed with two short ji polearms and leather armour, ensuring they are both fast and powerful on the battlefield. To be the chosen of the Eight Immortals is to inhabit their power and their spirit both.

Whatever cause these warriors used to fight for is gone; now they have a new purpose, if not the same zeal. It was Cao Cao that saved these former rebels from traitors' deaths, and though they swear their arms to a new cause, their hearts do not follow. \\n\\n Better armed and armoured than their other erstwhile rebel comrades, they suffer the same lack of morale for the cause. Yet on occasion, they will show a glimpse of their former fury, and be overtaken by a zealous warrior's rage!

The momentum of a cavalry charge is like waves crashing onto rocks to these heavily-armoured troops. Clad in iron armour, and equipped with a tower shield, they can form formidable defensive lines against the enemy. \\n\\n Their rectangular shield is tall enough to cover a soldier’s crouching body, and the small gaps in the formation enable them to thrust spears through at the enemy while remaining protected.

As an instrument of war, there are few threats more deadly than the swift and brutal cut of a sabre. Yet the men who bear them may prove more deadly still. Resolutely marching into the thick of battle to the rallying cries of their captain, these heavily armoured, expert infantrymen carve through the ranks of their opponents with a terrifying zeal. \\n\\n Should the northern tribes seek to cross the border in pursuit of war, this elite sabre infantry will make certain they find naught but the bitter taste of defeat.

Though the crossbow has many advantages, the traditional bow is a weapon of grace and power with a venerable history. Archery was listed as one of the Six Noble Arts, and has been practised by emperors and sages. A well-made bow in skilled hands is also a devastating weapon on the battlefield. \\n\\nTo increase the archer's effectiveness by firing flaming arrows might almost seem a step too far, were it not so effective.

The thrust of a spear is deadly enough; when it is in the hands of the cavalry and powered by the momentum of a horse in full gallop, it is almost unstoppable. The qiang is a one-handed spear known as the 'King of Weapons', with a scarlet tassel of horse-hair attached below the blade, denoting its elite status. \\n\\n The tassel both prevents the blood of its targets from making the shaft slippery and obscures the blade when wielded, making it harder to block and evade when thrust.

The Protectors of Heaven are soldiers personally selected by the emperor for their proven excellence and loyalty in battle. It is their loyalty and commitment to the great cause that ensures they never tire in battle, even when leading furious charges from the frontlines. \\n\\n To display and complement their status as the head of an army to enemies and allies alike, they wear magnificent armour and wield gou lian dao polearms, both items commissioned exclusively by the emperor!

Whatever exceptional training the ji infantry have – and it is exceptional – is honed to a sharpened point in these veterans. As part of the Han's northern army, they were trained to resist the savage, unorthodox warriors beyond the northern borders. \\n\\n As the soldiers who have survived such onslaughts, their skills are beyond doubt, to say nothing of the additional armour they have earned along the way.

The imperial palaces at Luoyang are the nexus of power for the Han dynasty, from which all authority flows outward across the realm. It is just, therefore, that the capital - and the palaces - are defended by the very best. \\n\\n The Imperial Palace Cavalry ride out armed with crossbows as well as sabres. This allows them to soften up enemies before a charge or ride at range whilst peppering the enemy with fire, because in defence of the dynasty, every strategy must be employed.

Spears are an effective defence against enemy cavalry, but can also be used offensively as well. \\n\\n These infantry troops grip their qiang spears in both hands and put their weight behind the weapon to pierce armour and drive it through to the enemy inside. \\n\\n Outfitted in partial iron armour, they are somewhat protected against enemy assaults, meaning they can concentrate on defeating their quarry.

Much like their mounted archer counterparts, mounted crossbowmen are valued for their manoeuvrability on the battlefield. A contingent of warriors able to fire from range then swiftly retreat from any counter-attack is a useful tool to any commander. The crossbow has a particular benefit over the standard bow, however, in that it is far easier to use. This means that anyone able to ride a horse can be handed a crossbow and easily turned into a lethal force in battle.

These heralds are eager to convert all who seek to deny the approach of the Yellow Sky. This utter certainty of the arrival of the Great Peace leads them to believe they are invulnerable, and there is some truth in it. \\n\\n Beneath their yellow robes and Taoist charms, they are well-protected by light armour, trained to parry blows with clubs, impossible to rout, and their charges shake the hardiest of enemies. However, their devotion can easily tip into frenzied fanaticism, sending them on an uncontrollable rampage.

Victory in battle is decided not only on the strength and skills of soldiers, but on strategic control of the field. These mercenaries fight for gold, not out of loyalty, so when ordered to capture a key strategic point they put all efforts towards it or risk not getting paid. \\n\\n Offering their services to the highest bidder, their travels have acclimatised them to even the most punishing heat. Upon accepting a contract, they arrive fully equipped with fine leather armour, rattan shields and good quality fu axes.

Whereas some cavalry bring a primal, instantly shattering force to the battlefield, other mounted warriors are suited to the slower burn, embroiling themselves in the melee and staying to continue inflicting casualties. \\n\\n These marauders carry dual axes into battle so, whilst they get less power on the charge, their destructive capability increases dramatically once they begin hacking away at foes.

The beauty of the polearm is that it is a fundamentally simple weapon - anyone can be handed one and immediately understand how it works and where it should be pointed. This is particularly useful for the Yellow Turbans, whose troops largely lack military experience and training. \\n\\n Although unlikely to last long against hardened soldiery, a swelling gang of warriors armed with spears and an abundance of zeal will nevertheless charge headlong into battle. When one becomes one hundred, even the most elite warriors will soon be overwhelmed.

What is considered a loss for the Han is inevitably a gain for the Yellow Turbans. So it is with territory, so it is with wealth, and so it is with troops. And who could blame the warrior, having heard of the promise of the Yellow Sky, for turning his back on the corruption of the Han and pledging his sword to another. \\n\\n With dao in hand, these cavalrymen ride now to secure a better future, shattering the enemy's lines as they shatter the Azure Sky itself!

The tiger warriors of Lady Zhurong are a sight to chill the hearts of all who face them. To fight with a tiger at your side is to enter the realm of legend, and the enemy would be wise to turn tail and flee. \\n\\nShould any foe find the strength to stand their ground, they must still face the handlers who control the great beasts, and who are highly skilled with their slings.

The momentum of a cavalry charge is like waves crashing onto rocks to these heavily-armoured troops. Clad in iron armour, and equipped with a tower shield, these warriors can form formidable defensive lines against the enemy. \\n\\n The rectangular shield is tall enough to cover a soldier’s crouching body, and the small gaps in the formation enables them to poke and thrust spears through at the enemy while remaining protected.

Only the most exceptional troops are given the honour of riding the purest of white horses; if the mounts' appearance are not enough to strike fear into their targets’ superstitious hearts, then the riders’ accuracy with their long siyah bows will surely intimidate. \\n\\n The horses are trained to ignore the din of battle, so their riders can harass enemies with arrows or attack with zhibeidao swords, without fear their horses will panic and bolt.

The zeal that radiates from some believers in the Yellow Turban cause is so potent as to be infectious to those around them, advancing the cause both in daily life and on the battlefield. \\n\\n Equipped simply with wooden staffs, these warriors nevertheless excel at holding their own whilst continually chanting encouragement to nearby comrades. Their weak armour, however, makes them susceptible to arrow fire. Yet whilst their bodies are transient, their souls and beliefs are always far beyond harm.

The spear is a simple weapon, and for the poorest fighters it may be little more than a sturdy bamboo cane honed to a point.  \\n\\nA spear keeps the enemy at arm's length, however, and can be used both to attack and defend. In the hands of big-hearted men who will do whatever it takes to defend what is theirs, spears can still take their toll in battle.

These riders are as fearsome as the great beasts they take their name from. Their role is to take on the enemy directly, thrusting their two-handed qiang spears while mounted. \\n\\n Their horses are conditioned to ignore the din of battle, and have such high stamina that they never tire from fatigue, making them excellent for charging, moving out of range and then striking again.

These warriors choose skill and the effective strike from a distance over the comforting but cumbersome weight of heavy armour and weapons. \\n\\nTheir armour is light, backed up with a shield; just enough to let them get into range without fear of being cut down. Each solider carries but a few of their well-crafted throwing axes, but they have the throwing ability to make sure every shot counts.
